Methyl anthranilate is also used in Perfumery, I use it myself. It contributes to the aroma of Jasmine and is naturally occurring in the flower. Interestingly enough when you react it with chemicals such as Aldehydes the formation of Schiff's bases occurs. For example Methyl anthranilate + Hydroxycitronellal forms a Schiff's base called Aurantiol which contributes to the aroma of Orange Blossom, this is also used extensively in perfumery.

If you want to avoid water (like in most esterifications), you may also consider bubbling HCl gas through methanol to saturate it. That way you can use dry methanol with HCl as the acid catalyst and no water.
Not sure if that would have made any practical difference on yield in this case, but in some cases that is a neat trick to to use when using methanol. This does not work generally with all alcohols because of the soluability of HCl is not too high on all alcohols.

Looks like a decent prep. A few thoughts: I don't think you mentioned the reasoning, but the large amount of sulfuric acid is needed because the aniline functional group of the anthranilic acid uses up one molar equivalent of sulfuric acid. You may have lost a considerable portion of your yield during the drying steps. Calcium chloride complexes amines (including anilines) and alcohols. You may have thrown out a fair portion of the product with the dessicant. Much better choices would have been anhydrous magnesium sulfate, calcium sulfate, or sodium sulfate.
